Can regular intake of cranberry juice or cranberry extract prevent recurrent cystitis in women? [SEP] (2) two randomised controlled trials involving a total of about 300 young women showed that daily use of cranberry juice or tablets reduced the relapse rate for acute cystitis: on average, treating 100 women for one year prevented at least 1 urinary tract infection in 15 to 33 women.

[SEP] : among otherwise healthy college women with an acute uti, those drinking 8 oz of 27% cranberry juice twice daily did not experience a decrease in the 6-month incidence of a second uti, compared with those drinking a placebo.

Does whole-body cryotherapy in the cold chamber improve health? [SEP] most clinical studies report that the use of cryotherapy has a positive effect on pain reduction and on the recovery of various injuries.

Does whole-body cryotherapy in the cold chamber improve health? [SEP] whole body cryotherapy, a relatively new form of cold therapy, consists of short whole-body exposure to extremely cold air (-110°c to -140°c).

Does whole-body cryotherapy in the cold chamber improve health? [SEP] this review focuses primarily on two methods of cold therapy that have received recent attention: whole-body cryotherapy and partial-body cryotherapy.

Does whole-body cryotherapy in the cold chamber improve health? [SEP] in whole body cryotherapy the whole human body is exposed to low temperature below -100 degrees c in a special room called cryogenic chamber for a very short period of time (2-3 minutes).

Does whole-body cryotherapy in the cold chamber improve health? [SEP] the aim of this review is to compare whole- and partial-body cryotherapy effects (especially on skin temperature) and to classify the protocols for exposure according to the desired effects.

Does whole-body cryotherapy in the cold chamber improve health? [SEP] whole body cryotherapy (wbc) consists of a brief exposure to extreme cold air (-110°c) in a controlled chamber and it is applied in sports medicine to improve recovery from musculoskeletal trauma.

[SEP] ozone major autohemotherapy (the return of a small amount of a patient's blood to the circulation after ex vivo exposure to ozone) has been reported to have a therapeutic effect in various pathological conditions, including ischemic, infectious, autoimmune and neoplastic disorders.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] preclinical data and a small number of clinical studies suggest that repeated short-term fasting may reduce the side effects of chemotherapy, enhance quality of life, and eventually slow down tumor progression.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] (1) background: the present review provides a comprehensive and up-to date overview of the potential exploitation of fasting as an anticancer strategy.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] this study is the first confirmatory, randomized controlled, clinical study, comparing the effects of short-term fasting to a short-term, plant-based, low-sugar diet during chemotherapy on quality of life and histological tumor remission.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] research reported in this issue of science translational medicine illustrates the benefits of short-term food withdrawal (fasting) in the treatment of cancer.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] short-term fasting (48 hours) was shown to be effective in protecting normal cells and mice but not cancer cells against high dose chemotherapy, termed differential stress resistance (dsr), but the feasibility and effect of fasting in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy is unknown.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] we sought to investigate the feasibility and effect of short-term fasting in patients receiving chemotherapy for gynecologic malignancy.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] fasting in disease prevention and treatment has recently become a popular topic, particularly in the context of oncology.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] fasting potentially improves the response of tumor cells to chemotherapy by (1) repairing dna damage in normal tissues (but not tumor cells); (2) upregulating autophagy flux as a protection against damage to organelles and some cancer cells; (3) altering apoptosis and increasing tumor cells' sensitivity to the apoptotic stimuli, and preventing apoptosis-mediated damage to normal cells; (4) depleting regulatory t cells and improving the stimulation of cd8 cells; and (5) accumulating unfolded proteins and protecting cancer cells from immune surveillance.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] fasting diet in cancer treatment has become an important topic since raffaghello et al.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] (3) results: there is ample nonclinical evidence indicating that fasting can mitigate the toxicity of chemotherapy and/or increase the efficacy of chemotherapy.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] short-term nutritional restriction (fasting) has been shown to enhance the efficacy of chemotherapy by sensitizing cancer cells and protecting normal cells in a variety of cancer models, including glioblastoma (gbm).

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] fasting may also sensitize cancer cells to chemotherapy.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] we investigate the effect of fasting on glucose metabolism and malignancy in crc.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] the six patients who underwent chemotherapy with or without fasting reported a reduction in fatigue, weakness, and gastrointestinal side effects while fasting.

Does short-term fasting improve quality of life in cancer? [SEP] it is further suggested that fasting may similarly augment the efficacy of oncolytic viral therapy.

Does honey help against acute cough in children? Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] these studies do not support a considerable decrease in the incidence of the common cold with supplemental vitamin c. however, vitamin c has consistently decreased the duration of cold episodes and the severity of symptoms.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] regular vitamin c supplementation (> or =1 g/day) has quite consistently reduced the duration of colds, but the size of the benefit has varied greatly.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] the effect of vitamin c on the common cold has been the subject of several studies.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] although the role of vitamin c in common cold incidence had been studied extensively, the level of vitamin c intake has not been unequivocally shown to affect the incidence of colds.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] the severity of colds was also reduced by regular vitamin c administration.seven comparisons examined the effect of therapeutic vitamin c (3249 episodes).

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] the combination of a regular daily supplement of vitamin c with extra dosage at the time of illness has been shown to reduce the disability due to common colds and other winter illness, but we have seen little effect on frequency of infections, sense of (well-being), or levels of serum cholesterol.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] in children, 1 to 2 g/day vitamin c shortened colds by 18%.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] nevertheless, given the consistent effect of vitamin c on the duration and severity of colds in the regular supplementation studies, and the low cost and safety, it may be worthwhile for common cold patients to test on an individual basis whether therapeutic vitamin c is beneficial for them.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] however, in four studies with british male schoolchildren and students a statistically highly significant reduction in common cold incidence was found in groups supplemented with vitamin c (pooled rr 0.70; 95% ci 0.60, 0.81).

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] the effect of vitamin c on preventing common cold in healthy adults has been investigated extensively, but not that of other micronutrients.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] doses of between four and six grams of vitamin c for the first three days of a cold may reduce its symptoms, but as long as vitamin c intake is adequate, long-term prophylaxis is not indicated.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] in the present study the six largest vitamin c supplementation (> or = 1 g/d) studies, including over 5000 episodes in all, have been analysed, and it is shown that common cold incidence is not reduced in the vitamin c-supplemented groups compared with the placebo groups (pooled rate ratio (rr) 0.99; 95% ci 0.93, 1.04).

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] nevertheless, in each of the 21 studies, vitamin c reduced the duration of episodes and the severity of the symptoms of the common cold by an average of 23%.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] the failure of vitamin c supplementation to reduce the incidence of colds in the general population indicates that routine vitamin c supplementation is not justified, yet vitamin c may be useful for people exposed to brief periods of severe physical exercise.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] these studies have not found any consistent evidence that vitamin c supplementation reduces the incidence of the common cold in the general population.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] nevertheless, the analysis was continued with the hypothesis that vitamin c intake may affect common cold susceptibility in specific groups of people.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] thus, these studies with british males indicate that vitamin c intake has physiological effects on susceptibility to common cold infections, although the effect seems quantitatively meaningful only in limited groups of people and is not very large.

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] five trials involving a total of 598 marathon runners, skiers and soldiers on subarctic exercises yielded a pooled rr of 0.48 (95% ci 0.35 to 0.64).thirty-one comparisons examined the effect of regular vitamin c on common cold duration (9745 episodes).

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] a large scale double-blind trial was conducted to test the claim that the intake of one gram of vitamin c per day substantially reduces the frequency and duration of "colds".

Can regular intake of vitamin C prevent colds? [SEP] the review found that micronutrients supplementation, except vitamin c, may not prevent cold incidence or reduce symptom severity among healthy adults. |||

[SEP] these studies do not support a considerable decrease in the incidence of the common cold with supplemental vitamin c. however, vitamin c has consistently decreased the duration of cold episodes and the severity of symptoms.

Can taking spermidine prolong life? Can it prevent diseases? Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] this review summarizes the current basic and clinical knowledge of zinc for the common cold, and suggests the present role of zinc therapy and future research needs.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] zinc (zn) has long been touted as a panacea for common cold.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] used prophylactically, oral zinc is associated with a reduced cold incidence in children.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] biochemical evidence suggests that zinc may be an effective treatment, and zinc gluconate glycine (zgg) lozenges have been shown to reduce the duration of cold symptoms in adults.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] these results provide evidence that zinc nasal gel is effective in shortening the duration of common cold symptoms off when taken within 24 hours of their onset.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] is oral zinc associated with a shorter duration, decreased severity, and reduced incidence of the common cold compared with placebo?

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] no consistently effective therapy for the common cold has been well documented, but evidence suggests that several possible mechanisms may make zinc an effective treatment.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] common cold patients may be encouraged to try zinc lozenges for treating their colds.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] when initiated within 24 hours of symptom onset, oral zinc is associated with a shorter duration of the common cold in healthy people.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] clinical studies have shown that ionic zinc (zn2+) dissolved in the mouth shortened manifestations of the common cold significantly, by an unknown mechanism.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] we studied a new approach to zinc therapy--an over-the-counter nasal gel formulation (zicam)--to independently evaluate its efficacy as a treatment for the common cold.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] there is no evidence that zinc doses over 100 mg/day might lead to greater efficacy in the treatment of the common cold.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] several controlled clinical trials have shown that zinc gluconate glycine lozenges can reduce symptom severity and duration of symptoms in patients with the common cold.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] oral zinc has been studied as a possible means of preventing or alleviating symptoms, with mixed results.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] five trials used zinc doses of 80-92 mg/day, common cold duration was reduced by 33%, and two trials used zinc doses of 192-207 mg/day and found an effect of 35%.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] previous studies have suggested that oral zinc supplementation can help reduce the duration of the common cold; however, the use of intranasal (in) zinc is strongly associated with anosmia, or the loss of the sense of smell, in humans.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] three trials that used lozenges composed of zinc acetate found that colds were shortened by 40% and four trials that used zinc gluconate by 28%.

Are oral zinc supplements effective for treating a cold (chill)? [SEP] recently, intranasal zinc gluconate has been recommended as a treatment for the common cold.

Is colloidal gold good for health? [SEP] colloidal gold has been studied for its potential application in medicine for centuries.

Is colloidal gold good for health? [SEP] colloidal gold, a sol comprised of nanoparticles of au(0), has been used as a therapeutic for the treatment of cancer as well as an indicator for immunodiagnostics.

Is colloidal gold good for health? [SEP] overall, based on the literature and taking low human exposure into account, elemental gold via the oral route is not considered to pose a health concern to humans in general.

Is colloidal gold good for health? [SEP] gold is a multifunctional material that has been utilized in medicinal applications for centuries because it has been recognized for its bacteriostatic, anticorrosive, and antioxidative properties.

Is colloidal gold good for health? [SEP] nowadays, gold is used in (nano-)medicine, usually in the form of nanoparticles, due to the solid proofs given of its therapeutic effects on several diseases.

Is colloidal gold good for health? [SEP] gold also plays an important role in the vaccine field as an adjuvant and a carrier, reducing toxicity, enhancing immunogenic activity, and providing stability in storage.

Does glutathione improve the tolerability of chemotherapy for cancer? [SEP] intracellular glutathione (gsh) has been shown to play an important role in modulating the cellular response to many cytotoxic agents, including radiation and chemotherapeutic drugs.

Does glutathione improve the tolerability of chemotherapy for cancer? [SEP] modulation of glutathione has been proposed as a mechanism to alter the efficacy and toxicity of chemotherapeutic agents.

Does glutathione improve the tolerability of chemotherapy for cancer? [SEP] glutathione, the most important intracellular thiol, has been implicated in modulating tumor cell sensitivity to alkylating agents and cisplatin.

Does glutathione improve the tolerability of chemotherapy for cancer? [SEP] although glutathione may have a role in modulating cisplatin cell sensitivity, it is unlikely that alteration in glutathione level and metabolism is a primary mechanism of cisplatin resistance in human tumors, since: a) no significant correlations were found between glutathione level and response to cisplatin treatment in a series of chemosensitive and chemoresistant human tumor xenografts; b) a marked increase in glutathione level might be responsible for cisplatin resistance but, in contrast to findings on cell systems selected in vitro for resistance, it is not a frequent event in human tumors.

Does glutathione improve the tolerability of chemotherapy for cancer? [SEP] glutathione has been shown to be an effective chemoprotector against cisplatin-induced side effects in patients with ovarian cancer.

Does glutathione improve the tolerability of chemotherapy for cancer? Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] this report provides an overview of health issues relating to the use of hydrogen peroxide, with an emphasis on safety with prolonged exposure to low concentrations of peroxide products.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] hydrogen peroxide is a highly reactive substance which can damage oral soft tissues and hard tissues when present in high concentrations and with exposures of prolonged duration.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] there is good evidence for the safety of hydrogen peroxide when used at low concentrations on a daily basis over extended periods of time, in self-administered oral health care products such as dentifrices and mouthrinses.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] this article discusses the truth behind these concerns and whether it is in fact safe to use hydrogen peroxide solution for wound cleaning in specific situations.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] ingestion of hydrogen peroxide is not an uncommon source of poisoning, and results in morbidity through three main mechanisms: direct caustic injury, oxygen gas formation and lipid peroxidation.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] morbidity and mortality have also been reported with the use of hydrogen peroxide in hospitals.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] a case of fatal oxygen embolism in a child after ingestion of hydrogen peroxide is reported.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] caution should be exercised with the increasingly higher concentration peroxide products used for 'walking' or 'power' bleaching due to the possibility of chemical irritation of oral soft tissues with injudicious use.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] hydrogen peroxide is not more effective than other antiseptics; its potentially serious risk should not be unrecognized.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] such risks can also result from using a sealed container to collect hydrogen peroxide that has mixed with body fluids (for instance, in a debridement procedure).

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] concern regarding hydrogen peroxide (h(2)o(2)) carcinogenicity arises from its ability to act as a strong oxidizing agent.

Does gargling with hydrogen peroxide have health risks? [SEP] hydrogen peroxide should not be considered to be innocuous; it should neither be ingested nor used in situations where the evolved oxygen gas cannot dissipate freely.

Can Echinacea protect against colds? [SEP] echinacea is an herbal supplement commonly used as an immune system stimulant to prevent infections, such as the common cold or flu.

Can Echinacea protect against colds? [SEP] echinacea decreased the odds of developing the common cold by 58% (or 0.42; 95% ci 0.25-0.71; q statistic p<0.001) and the duration of a cold by 1.4 days (wmd -1.44, -2.24 to -0.64; p=0.01).

Can Echinacea protect against colds? [SEP] recently, echinacea has regained popularity as one of the treatments chosen most commonly by consumers with the expectation that it will reduce the severity and duration of the common cold.

Can Echinacea protect against colds? [SEP] in addition to widespread use in reducing the symptoms of colds and flu, echinacea is traditionally employed to treat fungal and bacterial infections.

Can Echinacea protect against colds? [SEP] echinacea extracts have traditionally been used in the treatment of many infectious and other diseases (such as rhinovirus colds), and research has revealed the presence of various bioactivities in these extracts, particularly those connected with immune responses.

Can Echinacea protect against colds? [SEP] preparations of echinacea are widely used as alternative remedies to prevent the common cold and infections in the upper respiratory tract.

[SEP] echinacea supplementation may assist with the symptoms of acute respiratory infections (ari) and the common cold, particularly when administered at the first sign of infection; however, no studies using echinacea in the prevention or treatment of conditions similar to covid-19 have been identified.

Can light therapy with light lamps relieve the symptoms of autumn-winter depression? [SEP] the present study, a 1- to 2-week open trial of bright (greater than or equal to 2,000 lux) incandescent light with seasonal (fall/winter) and nonseasonal depressives, produced a therapeutic effect on seasonal depression, as measured by three criteria for recovery: final score on the hamilton rating scale for depression (hrsd) less than 10; final hrsd score less than or equal to 50% of pretreatment hrsd score; no longer meets dsm-iii criteria for major depressive disorder.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] to combat this pandemic, effective screening techniques for infected patients are indispensable.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] screening asymptomatic individuals to detect early unapparent conditions is an important public health intervention strategy.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] health checks identify (risk factors for) disease in people without symptoms.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] population-based screening is conducted to detect diseases or other conditions in persons before symptoms appear; effective screening leads to early detection and treatment, thereby reducing disease-associated morbidity and mortality.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] screening for disease control can be defined as a preventive technology that is used to examine asymptomatic people in order to classify them as likely or unlikely to have the disease that is the object of screening.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] for infectious diseases, screening can benefit not only the individual with the disease but also the community, since infectious persons can be identified and treated prior to transmitting the disease to others.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] health screening is defined as the use of a test or a series of tests to detect unrecognized health risks or preclinical disease in apparently healthy populations to permit prevention and timely intervention.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] screening programs involve testing asymptomatic individuals with an accurate screening test to identify those likely to have the disease of interest and to further investigate them to confirm or exclude the disease.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] the active check-over for disease among apparently healthy people is a fundamental aspect of prevention.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] screening is a diagnostic activity applied to whole populations, or defined sections of populations, with the aim to detect the signs of disease before there are symptoms.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] the purpose of screening is to identify asymptomatic disease, or risk factors for disease, so that interventions can occur as early as possible in the disease process.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] community-based screening has been promoted to augment efficiency of diagnostic services, but few data are available on the downstream impact of such programmes.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] even so, screening will succeed only if the condition has a high prevalence in the population being screened, in order that enough persons with disease are identified and treated to justify the cost and the stress experienced by screen-positive, disease-negative subjects.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] a decision to introduce a screening program in public health services depends on the evidence that the benefits outweigh the harms of screening, disease burden, availability of suitable screening test, effective treatment, adequate resources, and efficient health services.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] this is perceivable by screening, which is a search of unrecognized disease or condition by means of rapidly applied test, examination or other procedures in apparently healthy individuals.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] preventive screening is widely recognized as a key component of cost-effective, high-quality health care.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] symptom screening is a recommended component of intensified case-finding (icf) for pulmonary tuberculosis (tb) among hiv-infected individuals.

Are health checks of symptom-free individuals (screening) effective in containing the pandemic? [SEP] however, it is not clear whether health checks aimed at certain groups at high risk may reduce adverse health behaviour and identify persons with metabolic risk factors and non-communicable diseases (ncds).

Does melatonin help against jet lag? Does melatonin help against jet lag? [SEP] although melatonin is approved only for the treatment of jet-lag syndrome and some types of insomnia, clinical data suggest that it is effective in the adjunctive therapy of osteoporosis, cataract, sepsis, neurodegenerative diseases, hypertension, and even cancer.

Does melatonin help against jet lag? [SEP] relative to placebo, melatonin significantly improved the quality and depth of nighttime sleep, reduced the number of nighttime awakenings, and increased the duration of sleep without producing a morning hangover (p < .05).

Does melatonin help against jet lag? [SEP] oral melatonin -a pineal neurohormone normally produced during darkness and responsible for regulating the body's circadian rhythms- has been used as treatment for this condition. |||

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab reduced the incidence of new vertebral and hip fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis at higher risk for fracture.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab is a potent antiresorptive drug leading to significant reduction in the risk of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures in postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab significantly decreased the risk of clinical osteoporotic fractures in postmenopausal women.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab has been shown to reduce new vertebral, nonvertebral, and hip fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] in randomized controlled trials, denosumab has been shown to significantly reduce the fracture risk in women with osteoporosis.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab, a rankl inhibitor, reduced the risk of vertebral, hip, and nonvertebral fractures in the fracture reduction evaluation of denosumab in osteoporosis every 6 months (freedom) trial of postmenopausal women with osteoporosis compared with placebo.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] the freedom (fracture reduction evaluation of denosumab in osteoporosis every 6 months) trial showed denosumab significantly reduced the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab reduced bone resorption, increased bone mineral density (bmd), and decreased new vertebral, hip, and nonvertebral fracture risk in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis in the freedom trial.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] this paper presents a summary of the evidence review group (erg) report into denosumab for the prevention of osteoporotic fractures in postmenopausal women.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] we evaluated the effect of denosumab on the incidence of new vertebral and hip fractures in subgroups of women at higher risk for these fractures.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] studies in women with post-menopausal osteoporosis have shown that discontinuation of treatment with denosumab leads to an increased risk of vertebral fractures because of rebound bone turnover and rapid loss of bone mineral density (bmd).

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] compared with placebo, denosumab significantly reduced the risk of new vertebral fractures in women with multiple and/or severe prevalent vertebral fractures (16.6% placebo vs. 7.5% denosumab; p < 0.001).

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab has been shown to reduce the incidence of vertebral, nonvertebral, and hip fractures.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab is an approved therapy for postmenopausal women with osteoporosis at high or increased risk for fracture.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] in the freedom study, denosumab reduced fracture risk and increased bone mineral density (bmd).

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab has been shown in a large randomised trial to reduce the frequency of osteoporotic fractures when given subcutaneously at 6-monthly intervals.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab is an efficacious and safe osteoporosis treatment option, with current data from up to 8 years of continued use showing continued improvement in bone density with sustained fracture risk reduction.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab specifically inhibits the receptor activator for nuclear factor-kappa b ligand (rankl), and prevents osteoporotic fractures.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] denosumab reduced fracture risk to a greater extent in those at moderate to high risk.

Does denosumab (Prolia) reduce the risk of vertebral fractures in osteoporosis? [SEP] clinical vertebral fractures occurred in 0.8% of women taking denosumab and 2.6% of control subjects. |||

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] recent reports imply that denosumab discontinuation may lead to an increased risk of multiple vertebral fractures.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] denosumab discontinuation has been associated with increased risk of rebound-associated multiple vertebral fractures.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] studies in women with post-menopausal osteoporosis have shown that discontinuation of treatment with denosumab leads to an increased risk of vertebral fractures because of rebound bone turnover and rapid loss of bone mineral density (bmd).

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] there appears to be an increased risk of multiple vertebral fractures after discontinuation of denosumab although strong evidence for such an effect and for measures to prevent the occurring bone loss is lacking.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] discontinuation of denosumab is associated with a rapid return of bone mineral density (bmd) to baseline and an increased risk of multiple vertebral fractures.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] the vertebral fracture rate increased upon denosumab discontinuation to the level observed in untreated participants.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] denosumab discontinuation is associated with a rebound effect manifesting by an increased risk of multiple spontaneous vertebral fractures.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] we analyzed the risk of new or worsening vertebral fractures, especially multiple vertebral fractures, in participants who discontinued denosumab during the freedom study or its extension.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] clinical case series report multiple vertebral fractures after discontinuation of denosumab and a renewed analysis of freedom and freedom extension trial suggests, albeit does not prove, that the risk of multiple vertebral fractures may be increased when denosumab is stopped due to a rebound increase in bone resorption.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] recently, there has been concern about the discontinuation of denosumab and the increased risk of multiple vertebral fractures that would be associated with rapid bone loss due to high bone turnover and consequent increase in markers of bone remodeling, far above the baseline values.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] a majority of participants who sustained a vertebral fracture after discontinuing denosumab had multiple vertebral fractures, with greatest risk in participants with a prior vertebral fracture.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] of 1001 participants who discontinued denosumab during freedom or extension, the vertebral fracture rate increased from 1.2 per 100 participant-years during the on-treatment period to 7.1, similar to participants who received and then discontinued placebo (n = 470; 8.5 per 100 participant-years).

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] during a period of 28 months (september 2015-january 2018) 7 women presenting spontaneous vertebral fractures after denosumab discontinuation were attended in the rheumatology department of our centre.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] denosumab discontinuation is characterized by an increase in bone turnover overriding pre-treatment status, a rapid bone loss in the majority and multiple vertebral fractures (vfx) in some patients.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] the occurrence of multiple vertebral fractures was reported after denosumab discontinuation.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] recently, an elevated risk of rebound fractures following denosumab discontinuation was identified, unless patients were transitioned to an alternative antiresorptive medication.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] we hypothesized that denosumab influences osteocyte function contributing to bone reorganization and increased fractures during discontinuation.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] we hypothesize that rebound-associated multiple vertebral fractures after denosumab discontinuation may occur, at least in some cases, sequentially instead of simultaneously.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] based on current data, denosumab should not be stopped without considering alternative treatment in order to prevent rapid bmd loss and a potential rebound in vertebral fracture risk.

Does discontinuation of denosumab increase the risk of vertebral fractures??? [SEP] we report the cases of three patients, two females and one male, who had manifested rebound-associated vertebral fractures after denosumab discontinuation and sustained new vertebral fractures a few months later. |||

Does taking magnesium improve the symptoms of depression? [SEP] magnesium supplementation is associated with improved depressive symptoms, but because the mechanism is unknown, it is unclear whether serum magnesium levels act as a biological predictor of the treatment outcome.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] the ketogenic diet (kd), a high-fat/low-carbohydrate/adequate-protein diet, has been proposed as a treatment for a variety of diseases, including cancer.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] ketogenic diets are one strategy that has been proposed to enhance traditional anticancer therapy.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] low-carbohydrate, high-fat diets (ketogenic diets) might prevent tumor progression and could be used as supportive therapy; however, few studies have addressed the effect of such diets on colorectal cancer.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] we propose that dietary carbohydrate restriction, particularly ketogenic diets, may provide benefit as a therapeutic or preventive strategy in cancer, alone or as an adjunct to pharmacology.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] the application of ketogenic diet (kd) (high fat/low carbohydrate/adequate protein) as an auxiliary cancer therapy is a field of growing attention.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] recent studies have indicated that a ketogenic diet can be used as an adjuvant therapy to enhance sensitivity to chemotherapy and radiotherapy in cancer patients.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] ketogenic diet may be efficacious in certain cancer subtypes whose outcomes appear to correlate with metabolic status, but the results are not yet supportive and inconsistent.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] a dietary therapeutic strategy was proposed to inhibit tumor growth through administration of low-carbohydrate, average-protein, and high-fat diet, which is also known as ketogenic diet (kd).

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] recently, dietary modulation by carbohydrate depletion via ketogenic diet has been suggested as an important therapeutic strategy to selectively kill cancer cells and as adjuvant therapy for cancer treatment.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] this review summarises the evidence concerning the effect of oral ketogenic diets on anthropometry, metabolism, quality of life (qol) and tumour effects, at the same time as documenting adverse events and adherence in patients with cancer.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] the review focused on the results of human trials for cancer patients and checked the feasibility of using ketogenic diet for cancer patients as adjuvant therapy.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] ketogenic diet (kd), a low-carbohydrate-and-high-fat diet, causes a metabolic state of ketogenesis and has been used to treat drug-resistance epilepsy.

Does a ketogenic diet help against cancer? [SEP] the ketogenic diet (kd) is a very low-carbohydrate, high-fat, and adequate-protein diet that induces many metabolic adaptations when calorie intake is not limited.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] the deuterium-depleted water significantly decreased the growth rate of the l929 fibroblast cell line, and also inhibited the tumor growth in xenotransplanted mice.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] work with sub-natural levels of deuterium (d) in animals has demonstrated an anti-cancer effect of low d-concentration in water.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] deuterium depleted water delays tumor progression in mice, dogs, cats and humans.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] in vitro, in vivo and clinical studies have demonstrated anti-cancer effects of deuterium depleted water (ddw).

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] recent studies have demonstrated that natural water that has 65% of the deuterium concentration depleted, can exhibit anti-tumor properties.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] to investigate the in vivo and in vitro inhibitory effects of deuterium-depleted water (ddw) on human lung cancer and the possible mechanisms underlying these effects, we cultured and treated human lung carcinoma cell line a549 and human embryonic lung fibroblasts hlf-1 with various concentrations of ddw from 2 to 72 h. cellular growth inhibition rates were determined using the 3-(4, 5-dimethyldiazol-2-yl)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazolium-bromide) (mtt) proliferation assay.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] in oncological patients who also suffered from diabetes and were treated with deuterium-depleted water (ddw), an improvement of glucose metabolism was observed, and rat studies also proved the efficacy of ddw to reduce blood sugar level.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] it is found that consumption of deuterium depleted water reduces not only the content of deuterium in biological fluids but also more than 2 times reduces the d/h gradient value along the line: mixed saliva > blood plasma.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] despite the convincing empirical evidence that deuterium depleted water (ddw, 25-125 ppm deuterium) has anticancer effect, the molecular mechanism remains unclear.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] the role of naturally occurring d in living organisms has been examined by using deuterium-depleted water (30-40 ppm d) instead of water containing the natural abundance of d (150 ppm).

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] the patients received 1.5 l of water with reduced deuterium content (104 ppm instead of 145 ppm, equivalent 12 mmol/l in human) daily for 90 days.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] the experimental data showed that a physiological solution prepared on deuterium depleted water during induced apoptosis activates the dna repair system, significantly reducing the number of single-stranded dna breaks, which, in general, indicates an increase in the efficiency of defensive systems of the cell.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] ddw is proposed here to link cancer prevention and treatment using natural ketogenic diets, low deuterium drinking water, as well as ddw production as the mitochondrial downstream mechanism of targeted anti-cancer drugs such as avastin and glivec.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] deuterium-depleted water (ddw) has a lower concentration of deuterium than occurs naturally (less than 145 ppm).

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] our objective was to investigate whether deuterium-depleted water (ddw) can overturn reverse manganese (mn)-induced reduction in life span, using the caenorhabditis elegans (c. elegans) as a model system.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] treatment with different deuterium concentrations of ddw alone did not impose any significant inhibitory effects on growth of cell lines.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] deuterium-depleted water (ddw) is a water which has a 6-7-fold less concentration of the naturally occurring deuterium (20-25ppm vs. 150ppm).

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] the cell lines were treated with decreasing deuterium concentrations of ddw alone, paclitaxel alone and both.

Does deuterium-reduced water prevent cancer? [SEP] the effects of deuterium depletion on the human organism have been, except for the antitumor action, seldom investigated by now and the available data are scarce.

Does taking supplements with omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or other sudden cardiovascular problems?  Does it lower the risk of dying prematurely? [SEP] dietary supplementation with omega-3 fatty acids significantly reduced the risk of cardiovascular deaths (odds ratio [or]: 0.87, 95% confidence interval [ci]: 0.79-0.95, p = 0.002), sudden cardiac death (or: 0.87, 95% ci: 0.76-0.99, p = 0.04), all-cause mortality (or: 0.92, 95% ci: 0.85-0.99, p = 0.02), and nonfatal cardiovascular events (or: 0.92, 95% ci: 0.85-0.99, p = 0.02).

Does taking supplements with omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or other sudden cardiovascular problems?  Does it lower the risk of dying prematurely? [SEP] supplementation of omega-3 fatty acids (ω-3) has been associated with a decreased cardiovascular risk, thereby concentrating attention on a potentially preventive effect regarding tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac death.

Does taking supplements with omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or other sudden cardiovascular problems?  Does it lower the risk of dying prematurely? [SEP] more recent data, however, suggest that, in some patients with heart disease, omega-3 fatty acid supplementation may increase the risk of potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias and the risk of sudden cardiac death.

Does taking supplements with omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or other sudden cardiovascular problems?  Does it lower the risk of dying prematurely? [SEP] initial epidemiological, clinical trial and animal data have suggested that a diet high in omega-3 fatty acids reduces the risk of cardiac death and that this reduction in the risk was owing to the prevention of fatal arrhythmias.

Does taking supplements with omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or other sudden cardiovascular problems?  Does it lower the risk of dying prematurely? [SEP] omega-3 fatty acid supplementation reduces the risk of sudden cardiac death and death from any cause within 4 months in post-myocardial infarction patients.

[SEP] omega-3 fatty acid supplement use was independently associated with a lower risk of non-fatal ischemic stroke [hr (95% ci): 0.88 (0.81, 0.95)] but not non-fatal cad [0.99 (0.93, 1.06)].

Does taking supplements with omega-3 fatty acids reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or other sudden cardiovascular problems?  Does it lower the risk of dying prematurely? [SEP] current evidence suggests that individuals with coronary artery disease may reduce their risk of sudden cardiac death by increasing their intake of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids by approximately 1 g per day.

Is music therapy with rhythmic training helpful for people with Parkinson's who have trouble walking? Does taking vitamin K lower the risk of spinal fractures in older women? Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] compared with other vegetarian diets, vegan diets tend to contain less saturated fat and cholesterol and more dietary fiber.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] this review examines whether there is evidence that a strict vegan diet confers health advantages beyond that of a vegetarian diet or overall healthy eating.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] in terms of nutrients, vegetarian diets are usually rich in carbohydrates, n-6 fatty acids, dietary fibre, carotenoids, folic acid, vitamin c, vitamin e and mg, and relatively low in protein, saturated fat, long-chain n-3 fatty acids, retinol, vitamin b(12) and zn; vegans may have particularly low intakes of vitamin b(12) and low intakes of ca.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] the fat content of the vegan diet is significantly lower and the polyunsaturated:saturated fatty acid ratio higher than in the omnivore diet.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] few studies include vegan subjects as a distinct experimental group, yet when vegan diets are directly compared to vegetarian and omnivorous diets, a pattern of protective health benefits emerges.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] in western countries, vegetarian diets are associated with lower intakes of energy, saturated fatty acids and animal protein and higher intakes of fibre and phytochemicals, compared to omnivorous diets.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] a vegetarian diet is associated with many health benefits because of its higher content of fiber, folic acid, vitamins c and e, potassium, magnesium, and many phytochemicals and a fat content that is more unsaturated.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] these findings suggest that vegetarian diets are nutrient dense, consistent with dietary guidelines, and could be recommended for weight management without compromising diet quality.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] these results suggest that, although vegans have much lower intakes of dietary calcium and protein than omnivores, veganism does not have adverse effect on bone mineral density and does not alter body composition.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] cross-sectional studies of vegetarians and vegans have shown that on average they have a relatively low bmi and a low plasma cholesterol concentration; recent studies have also shown higher plasma homocysteine concentrations than in non-vegetarians.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] this cross-sectional study showed that, although vegans had lower dietary calcium and protein intakes than omnivores, veganism did not have adverse effect on bone mineral density and did not alter body composition.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] in conclusion, the available literature suggests that a vegetarian/vegan diet is effective in promoting a diverse ecosystem of beneficial bacteria to support both human gut microbiome and overall health.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] in most countries a vegan diet is associated with a more favourable cardio- metabolic profile compared to an omnivorous diet.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] from food frequency questionnaires in 28 studies, vegans compared to omnivores consumed less energy (-11%, 95% confidence interval -14 to -8) and less saturated fat (- 51%, ci -57 to -45).

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] differences in food composition, nutrient intake, and various health outcomes have been reported for vegetarians and non-vegetarians in the adventist health study-2 (ahs-2) cohort.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] vegetarian diets have long been thought of as beneficial to health.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] vegetarians exhibited a lower estimated prevalence of inadequacies for micronutrients such as antioxidant vitamins (e.g., for vitamin e, 28.9% for vegetarian women <55 years of age vs. 41.6% in meat-eaters) while vegans exhibited a higher estimated prevalence of inadequacies for some nutrients, in particular vitamin b12 (69.9% in men and 83.4% in women <55 years of age), compared to meat-eaters.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] vegetarian and vegan diets can vary widely, but the empirical evidence largely relates to the nutritional content and health effects of the average diet of well-educated vegetarians living in western countries, together with some information on vegetarians in non-western countries.

Is a vegan diet healthier than a vegetarian diet? [SEP] whether the corresponding health benefits in vegetarians outweigh the risks of nutrient deficiencies has not been fully clarified.

Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? [SEP] we found no evidence that the use of either aluminum-containing or non-aluminum containing deodorant adversely effects axillary skin reaction during conventionally fractionated radiation therapy for breast cancer.

Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? [SEP] the human population is exposed to aluminium (al) from diet, antacids and vaccine adjuvants, but frequent application of al-based salts to the underarm as antiperspirant adds a high additional exposure directly to the local area of the human breast.

Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? [SEP] if the use of aluminium-based antiperspirant salts is involved in the etiology of gross breast cyst formation, it might be expected that aluminium would be at elevated levels in human breast cyst fluid (bcf).

Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? [SEP] aluminium is known to have a genotoxic profile, capable of causing both dna alterations and epigenetic effects, and this would be consistent with a potential role in breast cancer if such effects occurred in breast cells.

Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? [SEP] the increasing exposure to aluminum has been linked with the development of different human pathologies (e.g., breast cancer, myofasciitis, neurodegenerative diseases), probably due to the consistent presence of aluminum salts in widely diffused cosmetic products and vaccines.

Can ingredients in deodorants like aluminum salts cause breast cancer? Do specially trained dogs reliably warn of dangerous hypoglycemia? [SEP] trained dogs often alert a human companion to otherwise unknown hypoglycemia; however due to high false-positive rate, a dog alert alone is unlikely to be helpful in differentiating hypo-/hyper-/euglycemia.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting has been proposed as a potential nutrition approach against obesity and metabolic disease.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] over the past 10 to 15 years, intermittent fasting has emerged as an unconventional approach to reduce body weight and improve metabolic health beyond simple calorie restriction.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting (if), a periodic energy restriction, has been shown to provide health benefits equivalent to prolonged fasting or caloric restriction.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting (if; severe restriction 1 d/week) facilitates weight loss and improves coronary heart disease (chd) risk indicators.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting does not improve weight loss compared to continuous energy restriction (cer), where energy intake is restricted every day.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting (if) is a dietary intervention often used as an alternative to caloric restriction (cr) and characterized by 24 hour cycles alternating ad libitum feeding and fasting.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting (if) regimens have gained considerable popularity in recent years, as some people find these diets easier to follow than traditional calorie restriction (cr) approaches.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting is a form of time restricted eating (typically 16 h fasting and 8 h eating), which has gained popularity in recent years and shows promise as a possible new paradigm in the approach to weight loss and the reduction of inflammation, and has many potential long term health benefits.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] intermittent fasting or alternate day fasting may be an option for achieving weight loss and maintenance.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] the potential health benefits of fasting can be related to both the acute food restriction and chronic influence of weight loss; the long-term effect of chronic food restriction in humans is not yet clear, but may be a potentially interesting future dietary strategy for longevity, particularly given the overweight epidemic.

Is Intermittent Fasting suitable for reducing excess weight as well as a conventional low calorie diet? [SEP] we tested the hypothesis that a one-meal-per-day intermittent fasting with high fat (hf) or protein (hp) diets can modify energy, lipid, and glucose metabolism in normal young male sprague-dawley rats with diet-induced obesity or overweight.

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? [SEP] contrary to previous recommendations, there is no strong evidence to suggest that fiber intake (including more fruits and vegetables) has any effect on colorectal cancer risk.

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? [SEP] although the association was not statistically significant for colorectal cancer overall (hr: 0.85; 95% ci: 0.70, 1.03; p-trend = 0.10), a reduced risk of distal colon cancer was observed with increased total fiber intake (hr: 0.62; 95% ci: 0.41, 0.94; p-trend = 0.03).

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? [SEP] many epidemiological and experimental studies have suggested that dietary fiber plays an important role in colon cancer prevention.

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? [SEP] whether the intake of dietary fiber can protect against colorectal cancer is a long-standing question of considerable public health import, but the epidemiologic evidence has been inconsistent.

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? [SEP] this large, prospective study within a population-based screening trial suggests that individuals consuming the highest intakes of dietary fiber have reduced risks of incident colorectal adenoma and distal colon cancer and that this effect of dietary fiber, particularly from cereals and fruit, may begin early in colorectal carcinogenesis.

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? [SEP] in analyses of fiber from different food sources, only fiber from grains was associated with a lower risk of colorectal cancer (multivariate rr(q5-q1): 0.86; 95% ci: 0.76, 0.98; p for trend = 0.01).

Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? Can switching to a higher fiber diet prevent colorectal cancer? Can perineal massage during pregnancy help prevent birth injury in first-time mothers? Can cancer be effectively treated with vitamin C infusions? [SEP] thus, a specific anticancer effect can be achieved at high doses of vitamin c therapy.

Can cancer be effectively treated with vitamin C infusions? Can cancer be effectively treated with vitamin C infusions? [SEP] especially in the public, vitamin c is considered supportive for the treatment of cancer and supplementation is common.

Do sweeteners increase the risk of type 2 diabetes or sugar metabolism disorders? [SEP] the intake of sugar-sweetened soft drinks has been reported to be associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, but it is unclear whether this is because of the sugar content or related lifestyle factors, whether similar associations hold for artificially sweetened soft drinks, and how these associations are related to bmi.

Do sweeteners increase the risk of type 2 diabetes or sugar metabolism disorders? [SEP] consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages has been shown, largely in american populations, to increase type 2 diabetes incidence.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] screening for breast cancer with mammography in women aged 50 years or more has been shown to reduce mortality from breast cancer.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] mammographic screening has been shown to reduce breast cancer mortality in women over the age of 50 years, and to a lesser extent in younger women.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] there is little controversy that mammography reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by about 23% among women between the ages of 50 and 69 years, although the harms associated with false-positive results and overdiagnosis limit the net benefit of mammography.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] mammography screening of women aged 50-70 years for breast cancer has proven to be effective in reducing breast cancer mortality.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] mammographic screening is one worthwhile way of reducing deaths from breast cancer among women diagnosed in ages 50-69.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] in randomized controlled trials, screening mammography has been shown to reduce mortality from breast cancer about 25% to 30% among women aged 50 to 69 years after only five to six years from the initiation of screening.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] screening for breast cancer using mammography alone, or mammography plus physical examination of the breasts, reduces mortality from breast cancer in women age 50-69.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] mammographic screening reduces mortality in breast cancer.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] while new data support a 16% reduction in breast cancer mortality for 40- to 49-year-old women after 10 years of screening, the net benefit is less compelling in part because of the lower incidence of breast cancer in this age group and because mammography is less sensitive and specific in women younger than 50 years.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] given that the incidence of breast cancer for women aged 40 to 49 years is lower and the potential benefit from mammography screening smaller and delayed, the absolute number of deaths prevented by screening women aged 40 to 49 years is much less than in screening women aged 50 to 69 years.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] in randomized trials, screening mammography has been shown to reduce breast cancer mortality.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] mammography screening is increasingly promoted as a means to avoid death from breast cancer.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] the benefits that have been realized from mammography screening in overall breast cancer mortality and diagnosis of earlier stage cancers are also reviewed.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] mammographic screening is effective in reducing mortality from breast cancer.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] the national breast screening study was designed to show whether screening with mammography and physical examination of the breasts reduces mortality from breast cancer in volunteers aged 40-49 and to determine the incremental effect of mammography over and above any effect of physical examination in women aged 50-59.in spite of the high incidence of breast cancer in these two age groups, both physicians and the public have shown reluctance to support the trial.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] women in their 70s may have a small benefit from screening mammography, but overdiagnosis increases in this age group as do competing causes of death.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] because the absolute benefit of screening women aged 40 to 49 years is small and there is concern that the harms are substantial, the focus should be to help these women make informed decisions about screening mammography by educating them of their true risk of breast cancer and the potential benefits and risks of screening.

Does mammography screening reduce the risk of dying from breast cancer in certain age groups? [SEP] the reduction in breast cancer mortality is greater for women aged over 50 at screening than for women aged under 50.

[SEP] although fluoride has been widely used in toothpaste, mouthwash, and drinking water to prevent dental caries, the excessive intake of fluoride can cause fluorosis which is associated with dental, skeletal, and soft tissue fluorosis.

Are electric cigarettes less harmful than tobacco smoking? [SEP] initially marketed for smoking cessation, electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) are commonly regarded as safer than combustible cigarettes because they usually contain less nicotine and do not use combustion.

Are electric cigarettes less harmful than tobacco smoking? [SEP] however, this has not been proved, and theoretical premises suggest that e-cigarettes should be definitely less harmful as while using them, tobacco is not burned and harmful substances, in particular carcinogens are not produced.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] we investigated whether mmr vaccination is associated with an increased risk of autism or other pervasive developmental disorders.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] the study strongly supports that mmr vaccination does not increase the risk for autism, does not trigger autism in susceptible children, and is not associated with clustering of autism cases after vaccination.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] it has been suggested that vaccination with the measles-mumps-rubella (mmr) vaccine causes autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] it has been suggested that vaccination, particularly with measles-mumps-rubella (mmr) vaccine, may be related to the development of autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] it has recently been suggested that mmr vaccine might cause autism, but that the induction interval need not be short.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] to evaluate whether the mmr vaccine increases the risk for autism in children, subgroups of children, or time periods after vaccination.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] the measles-mumps-rubella (mmr) vaccine has been postulated to cause a form of autism characterized by regression and bowel symptoms, and onset occurring shortly after vaccination.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] a report published in 1998, but subsequently retracted by the journal, suggested that measles, mumps, and rubella (mmr) vaccine causes autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] there is no proof that the overall risk of autism is higher in children who were vaccinated with mmr or of an increase in autism prevalence associated with the use of the mmr vaccine.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] despite research showing no link between the measles-mumps-rubella (mmr) vaccine and autism spectrum disorders (asd), beliefs that the vaccine causes autism persist, leading to lower vaccination levels.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] public fears of rising rates of children being diagnosed with autistic spectrum disorders has led to a fear that immunizations, specifically the measles-mumps-varicella vaccine (mmr), may trigger autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] case reports have described children who developed signs of both developmental regression and gastrointestinal symptoms shortly after mmr vaccination.a review of the literature revealed no convincing scientific evidence to support a causal relationship between the use of mmr vaccines and autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] several epidemiologic studies have not found an association between mmr vaccination and autism, including a study that found that mmr vaccine was not associated with an increased risk of autism even among high-risk children whose older siblings had autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] considerable concern has been generated in the lay and medical communities by a theory that increased measles-mumps-rubella (mmr) immunization among young children may be the cause of an apparent marked increase in autism occurrence.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] the hypothesis that mmr vaccines cause autism was first raised by reports of cases in which developmental regression occurred soon after mmr vaccination.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] a causal relationship between the measles, mumps, and rubella (mmr) vaccine and occurrence of autism spectrum disorders (asd) has been claimed, based on an increase in asd in the usa and the uk after introduction of the mmr vaccine.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] the hypothesized link between the measles, mumps, rubella (mmr) vaccine and autism continues to cause concern and challenge vaccine uptake.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] our results do not support this hypothesis, and provide further evidence against a causal association between mmr vaccination and autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] currently, the weight of the available epidemiological and related evidence does not support a causal association between mmr vaccine, or any other vaccine or vaccine constituent, and autism.

1. can MMR vaccination cause autism? [SEP] the belief that there is a link between the mmr vaccine and autism has led to a decline in childhood-immunization uptake and a resurgence of preventable infectious diseases. |||

Does homeopathy work better than a placebo? [SEP] through its relation with biomedicine, its doctrine, consultation design, and treatment rituals, homeopathy offers a powerful medium to elicit a placebo response in a therapeutic alliance.

Does homeopathy work better than a placebo? [SEP] we aimed to assess whether the clinical effect reported in randomised controlled trials of homeopathic remedies is equivalent to that reported for placebo.

Does homeopathy work better than a placebo? [SEP] we bracket the issue of biochemical effectiveness of homeopathic remedies as we only discuss homeopathy's potential to elicit a placebo response within its therapeutic alliance, in virtue of its social, symbolic, and material features.

Does homeopathy work better than a placebo? Does homeopathy work better than a placebo? [SEP] despite, a long debate is continuing whether homeopathy is just a placebo or more than it, homeopathy has been considered to be safe and cost-effectiveness therapeutic modality.

Does homeopathy work better than a placebo? [SEP] homeopathy seems scientifically implausible, but has widespread use.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] data from recent studies indicate that xylitol can reduce the occurrence of dental caries in young children, schoolchildren, and mothers, and in children via their mothers.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] xylitol, a polyol sugar, has been shown to reduce dental caries when mixed with food or chewing gum.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] xylitol, an over-the-counter sweetener, has shown some potential as a caries preventive agent, but the evidence for its effectiveness is not yet conclusive and is based largely on studies in child populations.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] xylitol is a safe dental caries preventive when incorporated into chewing gum or confections used habitually.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] xylitol is known to reduce caries by inhibiting the growth of streptococcus mutans.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] during the 5 years after habitual gum-chewing ended, xylitol gums reduced the caries risk 59% (rr, 0.41; 95% c.i., 0.23 to 0.75; p < 0.0034).

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] xylitol has been widely documented to have dental health benefits, such as reducing the risk for dental caries.

Does toothpaste containing xylitol reduce the risk of caries? [SEP] habitual xylitol gum-chewing may have a long-term preventive effect by reducing the caries risk for several years after the habitual chewing has ended.
