Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] serum igg and iga food antibodies have been used for dietary advice to subjects with gastrointestinal symptoms and perceived food intolerance, but the role of these antibodies in mediating intolerance is controversial.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] diagnostic food-specific ige levels might assist in diagnosing food allergies and circumventing the need for food challenges.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] quantification of food-specific ige is a valuable tool that will aid in the diagnosis of symptomatic food allergy and might decrease the need for double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenges.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] this article considers those assays useful in the diagnosis of type 1 hypersensitivity to foods (ige-based) and, importantly, discusses those assays where evidence is lacking for their use.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] since many patients believe that their symptoms are related to food ingestion without diagnostic confirmation of a causal relationship, tests for food-specific igg4 represent a growing market.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] it has been claimed that ige/igg4 antibody testing is a rapid and valid method of determining food intolerance.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] specific igg4 dosing against food is proposed to the public by a lot of commercial laboratories as a reliable method to diagnose food intolerance.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] in this study we evaluated the clinical utility of specific igg4 dosing against food in adult patients with suspected food allergy/intolerance.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] the usefulness of serum antibodies to common food antigens (immunoglobulin g4; igg4) assay in management of patients suffering from food intolerance was assessed.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] to understand the causes of food intolerance, it is important to investigate sensitization patterns of food-specific iggs (sigg) in relation to dietary patterns and physical conditions.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] in adult patients, testing for specific igg4 lacks clinical utility for the diagnosis of food allergy or intolerance.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] a case series of 73 adult patients with suspected food allergy and clinical manifestations of chronic urticaria or other allergy-supposed skin symptoms were tested for specific igg4 against foods.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] in conclusion, food-specific igg4 does not indicate (imminent) food allergy or intolerance, but rather a physiological response of the immune system after exposition to food components.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] diagnosing food allergy is often challenging, and validated testing modalities are mostly limited to immunoglobulin e (ige)-mediated reactions to foods.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] serological tests for immunoglobulin g4 (igg4) against foods are persistently promoted for the diagnosis of food-induced hypersensitivity.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] total serum ige is not a suitable screen for food allergy.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] specific immunoglobulins g and a (igg and iga) for common food items have been extensively measured as surrogate markers of food allergy, and dietary avoidance based on the test results advocated.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] use of food-specific ige tests and skin prick tests in individuals without a history that supports an ige-mediated reaction to the specific food being tested diminishes the predictive capabilities of the test.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? [SEP] therefore, testing of igg4 to foods is considered as irrelevant for the laboratory work-up of food allergy or intolerance and should not be performed in case of food-related complaints.

Are privately performed IgG tests to clarify food intolerances meaningful? Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] protein supplementation can enhance muscle protein synthesis after exercise and may preserve skeletal muscle mass and function in aging adults.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] athletes as well as elderly or hospitalized patients use dietary protein supplementation to maintain or grow skeletal muscle.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] protein supplementation increases muscle mass and strength gains during prolonged resistance-type exercise training in both younger and older subjects.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] it has been proposed that protein supplementation during resistance exercise training enhances muscle hypertrophy.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] protein supplementation has been suggested to augment endurance training adaptations by increasing mixed muscle and myofibrillar protein synthesis and lean body mass.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] protein supplementation showed a positive effect for ffm (weighted mean difference: 0.69 kg; 95% ci: 0.47, 0.91 kg; p < 0.00001) and 1-rm leg press strength (weighted mean difference: 13.5 kg; 95% ci: 6.4, 20.7 kg; p < 0.005) compared with a placebo after prolonged resistance-type exercise training in younger and older subjects.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] it is now well established that protein supplementation after resistance exercise promotes increased muscle protein synthesis, which ultimately results in greater net muscle accretion, relative to exercise alone or exercise with supplementary carbohydrate ingestion.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] increased amino acid availability stimulates muscle protein synthesis (mps), which is critical for maintaining or increasing muscle mass when combined with training.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] evidence has shown that protein supplementation following resistance exercise training (ret) helps to further enhance muscle mass and strength.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] whey protein is a supplemental protein source often used by athletes, particularly those aiming to gain muscle mass; however, direct evidence for its efficacy in stimulating muscle protein synthesis (mps) is lacking.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] provision of dietary amino acids increases skeletal muscle protein synthesis (mps), an effect that is enhanced by prior resistance exercise.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] consuming protein following exercise has been shown to stimulate protein synthesis acutely in skeletal muscle and has been recommended to prevent sarcopenia.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] protein ingestion following endurance exercise does facilitate an increase in skeletal mps, supporting muscle repair, growth and remodeling.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] protein supplementation during resistance training has a modest effect on whole-body lean mass as compared with exercise training without protein supplementation, and there was no effect on any outcome between protein supplement types (blend vs whey).

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] consequently, it is generally accepted that protein supplementation is required to maximize the adaptive response of the skeletal muscle to prolonged resistance-type exercise training.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] in this way, consuming dietary protein can complement intense exercise training and facilitate the skeletal muscle adaptive response.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] the objective of the study was to define the efficacy of protein supplementation to augment the adaptive response of the skeletal muscle to prolonged resistance-type exercise training in younger and older populations.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] it is recognized that high quality protein is needed for muscle accretion, and can be obtained from both animal and plant-based sources.

Do protein supplements help build muscle? [SEP] dietary protein is a pre-requisite for the maintenance of skeletal muscle mass; stimulating increases in muscle protein synthesis (mps), via essential amino acids (eaa), and attenuating muscle protein breakdown, via insulin.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] in practice, numerous drugs interact with grapefruit juice.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] drugs interacting with grapefruit and inducing serious clinical consequences (confirmed or very probable) include: immunosuppressants, some statins, benzodiazepines, most calcium channel blockers, indinavir and carbamazepine.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] several serious adverse effects involving drug interactions with grapefruit juice have been published in detail.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] grapefruit juice can increase or decrease the systemic exposure of myriad oral medications, leading to untoward effects or reduced efficacy.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] in spite of known health benefits of grapefruit juice, its consumption in combination with drugs requires caution.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] biomedical evidence in the last 10 years has, however, shown that consumption of grapefruit or its juice is associated with drug interactions, which, in some cases, have been fatal.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] unprocessed grapefruit can cause a drug interaction with felodipine.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] concomitant administration of grapefruit juice can increase the plasma concentration of numerous drugs in humans and decrease the concentration of a few others.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] this review is designed to provide a comprehensive summary of underlying mechanisms of interaction and human clinical trials performed in the area of grapefruit drug interactions and to point out possible replacements for drugs with a high potential for interactions.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] although only a few reports involving severe clinical consequences have been published, they suggest that grapefruit juice should be avoided during drug therapy, especially when the drug has a narrow therapeutic margin or carries a risk of serious dose-dependent adverse effects.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] these alternative drugs may be substituted if a patient experiences or is at risk of a grapefruit-drug interaction.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] however, since the early 1990s, the potential health benefits of grapefruit have been overshadowed by the possible risk of interactions between drugs and grapefruit and grapefruit juice.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] although furanocoumarins in grapefruit juice can interact with certain oral medications, noninteracting medications generally can be substituted.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] prominent medications known to interact with grapefruit include statins, antiarrhythmic agents, immunosuppressive agents, and calcium channel blockers.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] characteristics of oral medications that may interact with grapefruit include extensive metabolism through the intestinal cytochrome p450 3a4 system, low bioavailability, and a narrow therapeutic index.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] grapefruit is a rich source of flavonoids but also contains furanocoumarins, which are known to strongly interact with a variety of medications.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] one of the most prominent food-drug interactions is the inhibition of intestinal cytochrome p450 (cyp) 3a enzymes by grapefruit juice ingredients, and, as many drugs are metabolized via cyp 3a, this interaction can be of clinical importance.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] along with the variable composition of grapefruit juice, this makes it difficult to predict the magnitude and clinical consequences of drug interactions with grapefruit juice in a given patient.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] since the late 1980s, grapefruit juice has been known to affect the metabolism of certain drugs.

Can eating grapefruit in combination with some medications lead to harmful interactions? [SEP] any therapeutic concern for a drug interaction with commercial grapefruit juice should now be extended to include whole fruit and possibly confectioneries made from grapefruit peel. |||

Does skipping breakfast increase heart attack risk? [SEP] after adjusting for confounding factors, skipping breakfast significantly increased the risk of mortality from circulatory diseases [hazard ratio (hr) = 1.42] and all causes (hr = 1.43) in men and all causes mortality (hr = 1.34) in women.

Does skipping breakfast increase heart attack risk? [SEP] the primary meta-analysis combining hrs for q1 (first quartile, most skipping breakfast) versus q4 (fourth quartile, least skipping breakfast) from 3 studies together with other hrs/ors demonstrated that skipping breakfast was associated with the significantly increased risk of heart disease (pooled hr/or 1.24; 95% ci 1.09 to 1.40; p = 0.001).

Does skipping breakfast increase heart attack risk? [SEP] skipping breakfast is considered a frequent and unhealthy habit associated with an increased cardiovascular (cv) risk.

Does skipping breakfast increase heart attack risk? Does skipping breakfast increase heart attack risk? [SEP] the pooled data suggested that people who regularly skipped breakfast were about 21% more likely (hazard ratio (hr) 1.21, 95% confidence interval (ci) 1.08-1.35; i2 = 17.3%, p = 0.304) to experience incident cvd or die from it than people who regularly consumed breakfast.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] in the light of the proposal that dietary salt intake should be reduced as a community health care measure designed to lower blood pressure and consequently mortality and morbidity from stroke and heart disease, the evidence that there is a link between salt intake and blood pressure is reviewed.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] current epidemiology indicates that lower-salt diets tend to reduce coronary risk quite markedly in obese subjects, whereas the impact of such diets on leaner subjects (who are less likely to be salt sensitive) is equivocal--seemingly consistent with the possibility that salt restriction can exert countervailing effects on vascular health.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] a reduction in salt intake lowers blood pressure.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] we conducted a prospective cohort study to investigate whether an intensive low-salt diet education program effectively attenuated the rate of renal function decline in hypertensive patients with ckd.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] dietary salt restriction lowers blood pressure and has been advocated as a population-based strategy to reduce the cardiovascular morbidity associated with hypertension.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] this cohort study demonstrated that an intensive low-salt diet education program attenuated the rate of renal function decline in hypertensive ckd patients independent of its effect on lowering salt intake or albuminuria during the 36 months of follow-up.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] low-salt diets have potential for prevention and treatment of hypertension, and may also reduce risk for stroke, left ventricular hypertrophy, osteoporosis, renal stones, asthma, cataract, gastric pathology, and possibly even senile dementia.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] a reduction in dietary sodium not only decreases the blood pressure and the incidence of hypertension, but is also associated with a reduction in morbidity and mortality from cardiovascular diseases.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] these results demonstrate that a modest reduction in salt intake, approximately the amount of the current public health recommendations, causes significant falls in blood pressure in all 3 ethnic groups.

Does a lower salt diet reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] one of the controversies in preventive medicine is, whether a general reduction in sodium intake can decrease the blood pressure of a population and thereby reduce cardiovascular mortality and morbidity.

Do azo food dyes cause attention deficit disorder and hyperactivity in children? [SEP] we seek to assess whether artificial food colorings (afcs) contribute to the behavioral symptomatology of hyperactive syndromes.

Do azo food dyes cause attention deficit disorder and hyperactivity in children? [SEP] this review examines the research on mechanisms by which artificial food colors (afcs) and common foods may cause behavioral changes in children with and without attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (adhd).

Do azo food dyes cause attention deficit disorder and hyperactivity in children? [SEP] (1) a hypothesis has been proposed that artificial food colourings have a role in exacerbating hyperactive behavior in children; (2) a placebo-controlled, double-blind, crossover clinical study in 297 children representative of the general population showed higher hyperactivity scores during the periods when they were ingesting food colourings; (3) a meta-analysis of 15 double-blind clinical trials that evaluated artificial food colouring in children already considered to be hyperactive showed an increase in their hyperactive behavior; (4) in practice, even though the mechanism underlying this phenomenon has not be elucidated, these data suggest that it is best to avoid exposing children to artificial food coloring.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] human and animal studies have shown that green tea consumption is associated with a reduced risk of some cancers.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] green tea consumption has been linked to a reduced occurrence of some tumor types.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] epidemiological studies have associated the consumption of green tea with a lower risk of several types of cancers, including stomach, oral cavity, esophagus, and lung.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] the consumption of green tea is associated with a lower risk of several types of human carcinomas.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] daily green tea consumption was associated with a non-significant reduction in lung cancer risk.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] experimental evidence suggests that green tea (camellia sinesis) may reduce the risk of lung cancer through several hypothesized mechanisms including scavenging oxidative radicals, inhibition of tumor initiation, and modulation of detoxification enzymes.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] based on recent evidence that tea consumption contributes to a decreased incidence of human carcinomas, a number of investigators have focused on the mechanisms of cancer prevention by tea extracts, especially green tea polyphenols.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] a number of epidemiological studies suggest that the consumption of green tea reduces the incidence of prostate cancer.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] a number of epidemiological studies have suggested that consumption of green tea reduces the risk of prostate cancer.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] recently, an epidemiological study showed a lower risk of gastric cancer among people who consume a large amount of green tea.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] induction of detoxification enzymes has been suggested as one of the biochemical mechanisms responsible for the cancer-preventive effect of green tea.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] as the major catechins present in green tea are potent antioxidants, we hypothesized that genetic and cellular damage induced by oxygen free radicals could be significantly reduced by potent antioxidants in green tea, thus reducing the cumulative genetic and cellular damage with age, and slowing or preventing tumour formation.

Can green tea reduce the likelihood of dying from cancer ? [SEP] there is epidemiological evidence showing that drinking green tea can lower the risk of esophageal cancer (ec).

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] lowering of ldl cholesterol levels by plant sterols and stanols is associated with decreased risk of cardiovascular disease in humans.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] plant sterol-enriched foods are an effective dietary adjuvant in reducing cardiovascular risk by lowering total cholesterol and low density lipoprotein-cholesterol (ldl-c) in serum by up to approximately 15%.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] the consumption of products enriched with plant sterol or stanol esters lowers serum total and ldl-cholesterol concentrations, thereby most likely reducing the risk of coronary heart disease.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] plant sterol-enriched foods provides clinicians with a relatively cheap, safe, and effective way to help patients manage their cardiovascular risk.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] experimental studies show plant sterols to be an important part of the serum-cholesterol lowering effect of certain diets and dietary components.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] in conclusion, plant sterols and stanols effectively reduce serum ldl cholesterol and atherosclerotic risk.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] epidemiological data show that individuals with higher intakes of plant sterols from their habitual diets have lower serum-cholesterol levels.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] the consumption of dietary plant sterols should be a part of dietary advice to patients with hypercholesterolemia and the general public for the prevention and management of coronary heart disease.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] consumption of plant sterols or stanols (collectively referred to as phytosterols) and their esters results in decreased low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, which is associated with decreased atherosclerotic risk.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] reducing intestinal cholesterol absorption with plant sterol consumption is a well-characterized strategy to lower ldl-c and potentially reduce cardiovascular disease risk.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] dietary plant sterols, such as campesterol and sitosterol, reduce plasma cholesterol concentrations, but any relationship to plaque development and cvd remains unclear.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] plant sterols and stanols (phytosterols/phytostanols) are known to reduce serum low-density lipoprotein (ldl)-cholesterol level, and food products containing these plant compounds are widely used as a therapeutic dietary option to reduce plasma cholesterol and atherosclerotic risk.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] plant sterols, naturally occurring in foods of plant origin, reduce cholesterol absorption.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] products enriched with plant sterol and stanol esters selectively lower ldl cholesterol.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] serum concentrations of plant sterols and stanols were measured in samples from nonfasting subjects by glc-ms. intake of plant sterols was 1.1 +/- 0.6 g/d and was associated with a decrease of serum total cholesterol concentration of 0.25 +/- 0.91 mmol/l (4%, p < 0.05), a change that differed (p < 0.05) from the nonsignificant increase in nonusers (+2%, 0.12 +/- 0.78 mmol/l, p = 0.16).

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] plant-based sterol-supplemented foods are recommended to help reduce the serum low-density lipoprotein cholesterol level.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] it is unclear whether plant sterols regulate lipoprotein metabolism in the liver and intestines, thereby decreasing the levels of circulating atherogenic lipoproteins.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] beneficial in vivo effects of plant sterols and stanols on lipid and lipoprotein metabolism are well recognized.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] plant sterols and stanols are structurally similar to cholesterol and when added to the diet they are able to reduce serum total- and ldl-cholesterol concentrations.

Can plant sterols or foods with them reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] combining plant sterols with other dietary components known to reduce cholesterol in a portfolio approach has proven to be most effective for reduction of hypercholesterolemia and provide an alternative treatment option for clinicians. |||

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] more than adequate or excessive iodine intake may lead to hypothyroidism and autoimmune thyroiditis.

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] iodine may induce hypothyroidism in patients with autoimmune thyroiditis in a dose-dependent manner.

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] by interacting with the immune system, iodine excess may trigger the development of autoimmune thyroid disease such as lymphocytic hashimoto's thyroiditis (lt).

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] prolonged intake of large amounts of iodine has been reported to increase the incidence of hypothyroidism in humans, as well as in animals which are prone to spontaneously developing autoimmune thyroiditis.

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] iodine deficiency has been reported to facilitate the development of toxic nodular goitre, whereas a high iodine intake may increase the prevalence of autoimmune hypothyroidism.

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] chronic iodine deficiency leads to hypothyroidism, but iodine excess also impairs thyroid function causing hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and/or thyroiditis.

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] we observed an increase in the prevalence of overt hypothyroidism, subclinical hypothyroidism, and autoimmune thyroiditis with increasing iodine intake in china in cohorts from three regions with different levels of iodine intake: mildly deficient (median urinary iodine excretion, 84 microg per liter), more than adequate (median, 243 microg per liter), and excessive (median, 651 microg per liter).

Can too much iodine cause autoimmune thyroid disease and consequently hypothyroidism? [SEP] iodine is an essential component of thyroid hormones; high intake may lead to thyroid disease.

Is the sweetener aspartame harmful to health? [SEP] aspartame (asp), an artificial sweetener abundantly consumed in recent years in an array of dietary products, has raised some concerns in terms of toxicity, and it was even suggested a link with the risk of carcinogenesis (colorectal cancer), though the present scientific data are rather inconclusive.

Is the sweetener aspartame harmful to health? [SEP] the use of the artificial sweetener, aspartame, has long been contemplated and studied by various researchers, and people are concerned about its negative effects.

Is the sweetener aspartame harmful to health? [SEP] aspartame (α-aspartyl-l-phenylalanine-o-methyl ester), an artificial sweetener, has been linked to behavioral and cognitive problems.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] larger portion sizes of foods and beverages could affect overall energy intake at meals and promote overeating.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] while it is well-known that larger food portions lead to increased consumption (i.e., the portion size effect), previous studies confound the effect of the size and the number of food units making up the larger portion.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] the robust effect of portion size on intake has led to growing interest in why individuals consume more food when served larger portions.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] people typically eat more from large portions of food than from small portions.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] relative consumption ratios are higher when participants were served portions made up of enlarged food units compared to more food units.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] portion size is a key environmental driver of energy intake, and larger-than-appropriate portion sizes could increase the risk of weight gain.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] large portions increase intake and are hypothesized to contribute to the obesity epidemic.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] large portions of food are often blamed for rising rates of obesity.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] in building on the size-contrast illusion, this research examines whether the size of a bowl or serving spoon unknowingly biases how much a person serves and eats.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] in the past decades, portion sizes of high-caloric foods and drinks have increased and can be considered an important environmental obesogenic factor.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] the increase in the prevalence of obesity has coincided with an increase in portion sizes of foods both inside and outside the home, suggesting that larger portions may play a role in the obesity epidemic.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] in contrast to those in studies involving larger-sized plates and spoons, people serving from larger bowls felt more satiated.

Do large portions, large plates or glasses, and larger packaging cause us to eat and drink more? [SEP] portion distortion (perceiving large portion sizes as appropriate amounts to eat at a single eating occasion) may contribute to increasing energy intakes and expanding waistlines.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] evidence exists that a more acidic diet is detrimental to bone health.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] while it is clear that a high acid-producing diet generates increased urinary acid and calcium excretion, the effect of diet does not always have the expected results on bmd, fracture risk and markers of bone formation and resorption, suggesting that other factors are influencing the effect of acid/alkali loading on bone.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] high dietary acid load may be detrimental to bone mineral density (bmd), although sufficient calcium intake might neutralize this effect.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] we hypothesize that a slight, but significant, metabolic acidosis leads to greater loss of bone mineral and increase potential to fracture.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] acidosis-induced increases in cortisol secretion and plasma concentration may play a role in mild acidosis-induced alterations in bone metabolism and possibly in osteoporosis associated with an acidogenic western diet.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] this hypothesis posits that foods associated with an increased urinary acid excretion are deleterious for the skeleton, leading to osteoporosis and enhanced fragility fracture risk.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] imbalance between dietary acid and base precursors leads to a chronic net dietary acid load that may have adverse consequences on bone.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] these results suggest that, with a possible exception of older men, dietary acid load does not have a measureable negative effect on bone health, regardless of total calcium intake.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] a causal association between dietary acid load and osteoporotic bone disease is not supported by evidence and there is no evidence that an alkaline diet is protective of bone health.

Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? Can a supposedly "high acid" diet weaken bones? [SEP] on a more chronic basis metabolic acidosis alters bone cell function; there is an increase in osteoclastic bone resorption and a decrease in osteoblastic bone formation.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] here we provide evidence for the effectiveness of cognitive (often called "brain") training.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] brain training refers to practices that alter the brain in a way that improves cognition, and performance in domains beyond those involved in the training.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] does cognitive training work?

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] there is strong incentive to improve our cognitive abilities, and brain training has emerged as a promising approach for achieving this goal.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] "brain training" (i.e., enhancing, rehabilitating, or simply maintaining cognitive function through deliberate cognitive exercise) is growing rapidly in popularity, yet remains highly controversial.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] brain-training, aimed at advancing and improving cognitive and perceptual abilities, is vastly studied because of its immense promise.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] the potential impact of brain training methods for enhancing human cognition in healthy and clinical populations has motivated increasing public interest and scientific scrutiny.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] our study calls into question the benefit of cognitive training beyond practice effects, and provides a new framework for future investigations into the efficacy of brain training.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] in recent years there has been a significant commercial interest in 'brain training' - massed or spaced practice on a small set of tasks to boost cognitive performance.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] cognitive training is an effective tool to improve a variety of cognitive functions, and a small number of studies have now shown that brain stimulation accompanying these training protocols can enhance their effects.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] cognitive training should not only improve performance of the trained task, but also untrained abilities.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] the degree to which "brain training" can improve general cognition, resulting in improved performance on tasks dissimilar from the trained tasks (transfer of training), is a controversial topic.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] recently, researchers have combined cognitive training regimes with brain stimulation to try and maximize training benefits, leading to task-specific cognitive enhancement.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] we discuss the role of individual differences in brain function in training generalizability and make suggestions for future cognitive training research.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] we propose that future research should not investigate whether cognitive training works, but rather should determine what training regimens and what training conditions result in the best transfer effects, investigate the underlying neural and cognitive mechanisms, and finally, investigate for whom cognitive training is most useful.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] cognitive training can lead to performance improvements that are specific to the tasks trained.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] our findings suggest that working memory training in healthy older adults is associated with task-specific improvements, but these gains do not transfer to other cognitive domains, and it does not lead to structural brain changes.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] this work reviews how complex training environments such as action video game play may actually foster brain plasticity and learning.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] we conclude that cognitive training can be effective and long-lasting, but that there are limiting factors that must be considered to evaluate the effects of this training, one of which is individual differences in training performance.

Does brain training boost intelligence? [SEP] we argue that brain training includes network training through repetitive practice that exercises specific brain networks and state training, which changes the brain state in a way that influences many networks. |||

Are Vemma products good for health? [SEP] the healthy products offered in hvm accounted for 30%, 73%, and 52% of the total content, while cvm offered 6%, 32%, and 15% of the content, as assessed by who, npm-uk, and hsr, respectively.

[SEP] therapeutic footwear with specially-made insoles is often used in people with diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis to relieve ulcer risks and pain due to high pressures from areas beneath bony prominences of the foot, in particular to the metatarsal heads (mths).

Can shoe insoles relieve pain in people with high arches? [SEP] insoles are frequently used in orthotic therapy as the standard conservative treatment for symptomatic flatfoot deformity to rebuild the arch and stabilize the foot.

Can shoe insoles relieve pain in people with high arches? [SEP] in-shoe foot orthoses improve conditions such as plantar heel pain (fasciitis), probably due to their ability to raise the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and lower the stress on the plantar tissues.

Does the Aspire system help you lose weight? [SEP] the aspireassist system was associated with greater weight loss than lifestyle counseling alone.

Does the Aspire system help you lose weight? [SEP] the aspireassist® system (aspire bariatrics, inc. king of prussia, pa) is an endoscopic weight loss therapy utilizing a customized percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube and an external device to aspirate approximately 30% of ingested calories after a meal, in conjunction with lifestyle counseling.

Does the Aspire system help you lose weight? [SEP] the aspireassist system (aspireassist) is an endoscopic weight loss device that is comprised of an endoscopically placed percutaneous gastrostomy tube and an external device to facilitate drainage of about 30% of the calories consumed in a meal, in conjunction with lifestyle (diet and exercise) counseling.

Does the Aspire system help you lose weight? [SEP] this article will highlight the effectiveness of aspiration therapy as a novel and safe approach for weight loss in patients in obesity.

Can topiramate reduce the frequency of migraine attacks? Do today's children have a shorter life expectancy than their parents? [SEP] the life spans of parents and children appear only weakly related, even though parents affect their children's longevity through both genetic and environmental influences.

Do today's children have a shorter life expectancy than their parents? [SEP] it is shown that even if children perfectly inherit their frailty from their parents, parents' life spans explain little of the variance in children's life spans, because the variance in life expectancies among people with different frailties is small compared with the variance in life spans among people at the same level of frailty.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic medicines are clinically interchangeable with original brand medicines and have the same quality, efficacy and safety profiles.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] as more and more generic drug products become available in the marketplace, it is a concern whether these generic drug products can be used interchangeably in terms of their quality, safety, and efficacy.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic drugs are interchangeable with original proprietary drugs, as they have the same active pharmaceutical ingredients, dosage forms, strength, quality, indications, effects, directions, and dosage.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic medications offer substantial potential cost savings to health systems compared to their branded counterparts.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic drugs are considered therapeutically equivalent to their original counterparts and lower in acquisition costs.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] however, there is concern among patients and physicians that brand-name drugs may be clinically superior to generic drugs.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] in general, a generic drug is considered interchangeable with the original formulated drug.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic drugs are widely prescribed by physicians, although there is disagreement over the clinical comparability of generic drugs to brand-name drugs within the physician community.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] to test whether (1) generics and original products yield the same health outcomes, and (2) generic therapies save economic resources versus original therapies.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] case studies are discussed to demonstrate that generic pharmaceuticals are therapeutically equivalent to the branded product, even though the color, size, shape, and excipients utilized may not be identical.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] in conclusion, generic medications were at least similar, and in some cases superior, to their branded counterparts regarding mortality and major cardiovascular events.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic drugs are considered the best alternative for the originator brand drugs because they have the same quality, safety, and efficacy yet offered at considerbaly lower cost.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] the availability of generic products of antiepileptic drugs (aeds) has raised the following concerns: (1) do generic aeds work as well as brand aeds in terms of their efficacy, safety and quality?

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic drugs are equivalent to the brand formulation if they have the same active substance, the same pharmaceutical form and the same therapeutic indications and a similar bioequivalence respect to the reference medicinal product.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] generic drugs are cost-effective versions of brand-name drugs approved by the food and drug administration (fda) following proof of pharmaceutical equivalence and bioequivalence.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] thus, while providing the same therapeutic outcomes, generic medicines lead to substantial savings for healthcare systems.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] the united states food and drug administration (fda) indicates that an approved generic drug product can serve as a substitute for the innovative drug product.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] the global pharmaceutical industry consists of innovators and generics.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] studies compared generic and brand-name cardiovascular drugs using clinical efficacy and safety end points.

Do generic drugs work as well as original drugs? [SEP] use of generic drugs, which are bioequivalent to brand-name drugs, can help contain prescription drug spending. |||

Can lack of sleep cause obesity? [SEP] prospective studies suggest reduced habitual sleep duration as assessed by self-report is an independent risk factor for an increased rate of weight gain and incident obesity.

Can lack of sleep cause obesity? [SEP] background: sleep loss contributes to obesity through a variety of mechanisms, including neuroendocrine functioning, increased hunger, and increased food intake.

Can lack of sleep cause obesity? [SEP] several pathways could link sleep deprivation to weight gain and obesity, including increased food intake, decreased energy expenditure, and changes in levels of appetite-regulating hormones, such as leptin and ghrelin.

Can lack of sleep cause obesity? [SEP] the association between marijuana use and the prevalence of prediabetes and diabetes was examined in 3,034 participants at cardia examination year 25 (2010-2011), while the incidence of prediabetes and diabetes according to previous marijuana use was assessed in 3,151 individuals who were free from prediabetes/diabetes at year 7 (1992-1993) and who returned for at least one of the four subsequent follow-up examinations over 18 years.

Does marijuana use reduce the risk of developing diabetes? [SEP] marijuana use in young adulthood is associated with an increased risk of prediabetes by middle adulthood, but not with the development of diabetes by this age.

Does marijuana use reduce the risk of developing diabetes? [SEP] over 18 years of follow-up, a greater risk of prediabetes (but not diabetes) was found for individuals who reported a lifetime use of marijuana of 100 times or more (hr 1.39 [95% ci 1.13, 1.71]), compared with individuals who had never used marijuana.

Does marijuana use reduce the risk of developing diabetes? [SEP] after multivariable adjustment, higher odds of prediabetes were found for individuals who reported current use of marijuana (or 1.65 [95% ci 1.15, 2.38]) and a lifetime use of 100 times or more (or 1.49 [95% ci 1.06, 2.11]), compared with individuals who reported never using marijuana.

Does taking the birth control pill adversely affect mate choice? Does taking the birth control pill adversely affect mate choice? (Reader inquiry) [SEP] to test whether altered preference during pill use influences actual partner choice, we examined facial characteristics in 170 age-matched male partners of women who reported having either been using or not using the pill when the partnership was formed.

Does taking the birth control pill adversely affect mate choice? (Reader inquiry) [SEP] both facial measurements and perceptual judgements demonstrated that partners of women who used the pill during mate choice have less masculine faces than partners of women who did not use hormonal contraception at this time.

Does taking the birth control pill adversely affect mate choice? (Reader inquiry) [SEP] our data (a) provide the first experimental evidence that initiation of pill use in women causes changes in facial preferences and (b) documents downstream effects of these changes on real-life partner selection.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] ecological studies show that sun or ultraviolet (uv) exposure have inverse associations with blood pressure (bp) and cardiovascular disease (cvd).

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] although exposure to ultraviolet light is often viewed as pathogenic owing to its role in the genesis of skin cancer and skin aging, there is growing epidemiological evidence that such exposure may decrease risk for a number of more serious cancers, may have a favorable impact on blood pressure and vascular health, and may help to prevent certain autoimmune disorders - in addition to its well-known influence on bone density.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] exposure to sunlight may limit cardiometabolic risk.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] previous studies have shown that ultraviolet light can lead to the release of nitric oxide from the skin and decrease blood pressure.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] an hypothesis is put forward that uv radiation, by increasing body levels of vitamin d, protects against cvd by decreasing the risk of thrombus formation.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] there are considerable data to suggest that protection from solar ultraviolet (uv) radiation will reduce the risk of acute and chronic skin damage in humans.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] this review has identified a small body of evidence that suggests sun exposure protects against high bp and cvd, but further research is required to determine if this is independent of vitamin d.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] recent findings suggest that ultraviolet (uv) radiation exposure may reduce risk of developing non-hodgkin lymphoma (nhl), but the biologic basis for this relationship remains unclear.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] contractile responses of arteries that had been exposed to uv light were significantly reduced on days, 1, 7 and 14.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] these results suggest that the long-term effect of uv light is an attenuation of smooth muscle contractility without impairment of endothelial function.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] (2014) show that uva decreases blood pressure and increases blood flow and heart rate in humans, which is beneficial to the cardiovascular system.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] in our previous studies, regular exposure to sub-erythemal (non-burning) ultraviolet radiation (uvr) reduced signs of adiposity and cardiometabolic dysfunction in mice fed a high-fat diet.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] we therefore studied the long-term effects of uv using rat carotid arteries treated with uv-b light (wavelength = 313 nm, total energy = 14 mj/mm2).

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] however, it remains unknown whether uvb irradiation prevents an immunoinflammatory disease of arteries such as atherosclerosis.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] here, we investigated whether whole body exposure to visible blue light can also decrease blood pressure and increase endothelial function in healthy subjects.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] the relationship of ischaemic heart disease (ihd) to seasonal and latitude variation has prompted speculation that exposure to the ultraviolet component of solar radiation may reduce ihd risk.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] these results suggest that there may be a number of benefits achieved by regular exposure to safe (non-burning) levels of sunlight or uv-containing phototherapy, with effects potentially dependent on the predominance of the wavelengths of uvr administered.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] several studies have shown that uv irradiation may be effective for preventing vascular restenosis or vasopasm.

Does UV light reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease? [SEP] the ultraviolet (uv) portion of sunlight is involved in the induction and development of skin cancers against which a limited photoprotection may be provided by reduced time of exposure, clothing, and sunscreen applications.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] religion and spirituality have the ability to promote or damage mental health.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] recent research has suggested that religion may play an important role in determining mental health.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] studies indicate that religion and spirituality can promote mental health through positive religious coping, community and support, and positive beliefs.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] this article reviews recent advances in the domain of psychiatry and religion that highlight the double-edged capacity of religion to enhance or damage health and well-being, particularly among psychiatric patients.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] it is well documented that religion has an impact on mental health of both healthy people and mental health patients.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] this article reviews recent research into the capacity of religion and spirituality to benefit or harm the mental health of believers.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] although previous research suggests that increased religiosity is associated with better mental health and many authors have conjectured that religion-based social support may help explain this connection, scant research has directly examined whether religion-based support mediates religiosity and mental health.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] several investigations show that religious participation is related with better outcomes for persons who are recovering from physical and mental illness, also the psychology science have committed special issues to positive correlations between religious belief and practice, mental and physical health and longevity.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] as a part of human spirituality, religion has been theorized to influence the health of the individual, both positively and negatively.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] a recent systematic review of research on religion and health has found a consistent relationship between religion and better mental health as well as greater social support.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] there has been increased interest in the relationship between religion and spirituality and mental health in recent years.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] this article reviews the major empirical data on religion and mental health that are pertinent to nursing.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] however, a growing body of evidence indicates an association between mental health and various religious activities, both private and public.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] a significant relation between religion and better health has been demonstrated in a variety of healthy and patient populations.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] admittedly, religion frequently plays a role in psychopathology.

Does religion promote mental health? [SEP] research also shows that religion and spirituality can be damaging to mental health by means of negative religious coping, misunderstanding and miscommunication, and negative beliefs. |||

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] recent epidemiological studies have found a correlation between circulating phthalate levels and type 2 diabetes, whereas animal studies indicate that phthalates are capable of disrupting endocrine signaling.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] epidemiologic studies suggest phthalate metabolite concentrations are associated with type 2 diabetes.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] human exposure to phthalates is ubiquitous and has received considerable attention due to their association with adverse health outcomes, including type 2 diabetes mellitus (t2dm).

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] epidemiological studies suggest a positive relationship between phthalate exposure and diabetes.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] this study indicates that exposure to phthalates gives rise to a brief interference of glucose homeostasis but has little impact on the development of type 2 diabetes and atherosclerosis in apoe(-/-) mice.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] phthalate plasticizers used in a wide range of common plastic products are released into the environment and may pose a risk of increased incidence of type 2 diabetes.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] epidemiological studies have associated serum or urinary phthalate metabolites with the prevalence of type 2 diabetes or related phenotypes.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] bisphenol a (bpa) and phthalates are common environmental contaminants that have been proposed to influence incidence and development of types 1 and 2 diabetes.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] the most frequently occurring phthalate, di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (dehp), causes adverse effects on glucose homeostasis and insulin sensitivity in several cell models and epidemiological studies.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] however, direct evidence supporting a causal role for exposure to phthalates in type 2 diabetes is lacking.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] our study suggests that human exposure to phthalates is associated with increased oxidative stress which mediates the development of t2dm.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] phthalates are suspected to act as endocrine modulators in humans and exert reproductive toxicity.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] insulin tolerance test on non-fasted mice 3 weeks after treatment revealed that phthalate had little influence on insulin sensitivity though phthalate-treated mice had a higher glucose concentration (159.2 ± 6.0 vs. 145.2 ± 3.6 mg/dl; p = 0.086).

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] two weeks after treatment, phthalate-exposed mice had significantly higher fasting blood glucose level (97.9 ± 2.1 vs. 84.3 ± 5.3 mg/dl, p = 0.034) and exhibited a trend of increased glucose intolerance compared to control mice.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] epidemiological studies suggest that phthalate exposure is associated with development or worsening of allergic diseases such as asthma.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] however, little is known about the impact of dibutyl phthalate (dbp) exposure on the development of diabetes.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] to determine the potential influence of phthalates on glucose homeostasis and atherosclerosis, female apolipoprotein e-deficient (apoe(-/-)) mice were started at 6 weeks of age on a western diet together with or without bis-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] little is known about phthalates and gdm risk factors (i.e.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? [SEP] phthalate exposure may induce reproductive toxicity, liver damage, and carcinogenesis in humans.

Can phthalates cause diabetes? Does increased time outdoors inhibit myopia in children? [SEP] recent epidemiological evidence suggests that children who spend more time outdoors are less likely to be, or to become myopic, irrespective of how much near work they do, or whether their parents are myopic.

Does increased time outdoors inhibit myopia in children? [SEP] a significant protective effect of outdoor time was found for incident myopia (clinical trials: risk ratio (rr) = 0.536, 95% confidence interval (ci) = 0.338 to 0.850; longitudinal cohort studies: rr = 0.574, 95% ci = 0.395 to 0.834) and prevalent myopia (cross-sectional studies: or = 0.964, 95% ci = 0.945 to 0.982).

Does increased time outdoors inhibit myopia in children? [SEP] increased time outdoors is effective in preventing the onset of myopia as well as in slowing the myopic shift in refractive error.

Does increased time outdoors inhibit myopia in children? [SEP] according to research data from 13 studies of 15,081 children aged 4-14 at baseline, outdoor light exposure significantly reduced myopia incidence/prevalence (odds ratio [or] = 0.85, 95% confidence interval [ci]: 0.80-0.91, p < 0.00001; i2 = 90%), spherical equivalent refractive error (ser) by 0.15 d/year (0.09-0.27, p < 0.0001), and axial elongation by 0.08 mm/year (-0.14 to -0.02, p = 0.02).

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] while there is growing evidence that osteopathy is effective in a range of clinical conditions, the underlying biological basis of its therapeutic effects remain largely unknown.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopathy is an increasingly popular health care modality to address pain and function in the musculoskeletal system, organs and the head region, as well as functional somatic syndromes.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopathic medicine is based on a diagnostic and therapeutic system to treat tissue mobility/ motility dysfunctions in general, using different approaches (depending on the target tissue) known as osteopathic manipulative treatment.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] although osteopathic medicine has been well integrated into traditional health care systems in the united states, little is known about the role of osteopathy in traditional health care systems outside the united states.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopathic medicine is a system of manual diagnosis and treatment.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopathic care may support an individual's adaptive capacity, including allostatic regulation and tissue changes in both health and disease.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] though osteoporosis is a significant cause of disability worldwide, treatment with pharmacologic agents decreases risk of fragility fracture.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopathic manipulative treatment has been reported to relieve a variety of conditions, but no studies have examined the outcome effects of osteopathic manipulative treatment as a complementary modality for treating musculoskeletal problems during postoperative recovery.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] despite the value that osteopathic manipulative medicine (omm) may offer to healthcare consumers in a managed care, evidence-based healthcare system, very little research has been published on the cost-effectiveness of osteopathic manipulative treatment compared with other treatment modalities.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] though these treatments act through the bone remodeling system to improve bone mass, it is unclear if they alter the response of bone to mechanical loading at the level of the osteocyte.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] research on the effect of osteopathic manipulative therapy (omth; manipulative care provided by foreign-trained osteopaths) on chronic symptoms of multiple sclerosis (ms) is lacking.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] the conduct of evidence-based osteopathic research is imperative not only for scientific, economic, and professional reasons, but also to drive health care policy and clinical practice guidelines.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopaths, like other health care providers, are under increasing pressure to deliver evidence-based health care and to improve patient outcomes.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] therefore, it is incumbent on the osteopathy community to gather evidence in order to practice scientifically informed effective methods.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] although there is little evidence-based literature regarding osteopathic manipulative treatment for ophthalmic conditions, the general principles and techniques of osteopathic manipulative medicine can be used to manage various ophthalmic pathologic conditions.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] the nature of primary reasons for osteopathic consultations, coupled with documented satisfaction of patients with this approach, suggest a future for multidisciplinary collaborative health care including osteopathy.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] osteopathy is a discipline emphasizing the conservative treatment of the disease in an olistic vision.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] this paper summarizes recent studies in response to the osteopathic research challenge, including clinical trials registered with clinicaltrials.gov and a systematic review and meta-analysis of osteopathic manipulative treatment (omt) for low back pain.

Does osteopathy work? [SEP] the authors conclude that the osteopathic medical profession needs to conduct and publish research that is consistent with current practices in the conventional medical literature. |||

Is Exemestane better than other hormone-altering drugs for reducing the risk of breast cancer or treating it? [SEP] the benefits and risks of exemestane for the primary prevention of breast cancer are discussed and compared with other breast cancer chemoprevention therapies.

Is Exemestane better than other hormone-altering drugs for reducing the risk of breast cancer or treating it? [SEP] a study of 4560 high-risk postmenopausal women taking exemestane 25 mg daily for a median of three years found a 65% relative reduction in the annual occurrence of invasive breast cancer compared with placebo (0.19% versus 0.55%; hazard ratio, 0.35; 95% confidence interval [ci], 0.18-0.70; p = 0.002) and a 53% reduction in invasive plus noninvasive breast cancer (0.35% versus 0.77%; hazard ratio, 0.47; 95% ci, 0.27-0.79; p = 0.04).

[SEP] in two large, 1-year, randomized, open-label, multicentre, phase iii trials in healthy adult women (aged 18-50 years), nomegestrol acetate/estradiol was at least as effective as drospirenone/ethinylestradiol as contraceptive therapy, as the pregnancy rates in women aged 18-35 years (primary efficacy population) in terms of the pearl index (primary endpoint) were numerically lower with nomegestrol acetate/estradiol, although the between-group difference was not statistically significant.

[SEP] combined oral contraceptives (cocs) containing the progestins--gestodene, desogestrel or norgestimate--were developed to minimize androgenic side effects and are considered an effective, well-tolerated contraceptive option.

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? [SEP] the contraceptive pill containing estradiol valerate and dienogest meets women's requests for: a more natural contraceptive, that is reliable and easy to use, with positive cosmetic effects; less intense and shorter bleeding, reduced anaemia and increased vital energy; reduced dysmenorrhoea and all the specific cycle-related symptoms linked to a drop in oestrogen and the related systemic inflammation, the result of a hormone free interval (hfi) of just two days; with a good impact on sexuality and overall well-being, all associated with a high level of efficacy: (uncorrected pearl index: 0.79; corrected: 0.42).

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? [SEP] studies indicate that this formulation may be associated with decreased hepatic activation compared to contraceptive pills that contain ethinyl estradiol.

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? [SEP] the new pill containing estradiol valerate and dienogest may satisfy women's need for: a more natural hormonal contraceptive with a low hormone dosage, high reliability and good tolerability; a simple dosing schedule (one pill per day for 28 days); a positive cosmetic effect on the skin; lighter and shorter withdrawal bleeding, improved anaemia, less fatigue and higher vital energy; reduced dysmenorrhoea and a dramatic reduction in all symptoms thanks to a shorter hormone free interval (hfi) of just two days.

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? [SEP] to compare the effects of a monophasic combined oral contraceptive containing nomegestrol acetate/17β-estradiol (nomac/e2) on bone mineral density with a combined oral contraceptive containing levonorgestrel/ethinylestradiol (lng/ee).

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? [SEP] gestodene achieves contraceptive efficacy with the lowest dose of any progestin in a coc, and has an established and favorable short- and long-term tolerability profile.

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? [SEP] the pill containing estradiol valerate and dienogest is a contraceptive option that may satisfy women's demands for a more natural contraceptive while offering high reliability, good tolerability, a simple dosing schedule, lighter and shorter withdrawal bleeding, improved anaemia and a reduction in cycle-related symptoms thanks to a shorter hormone free interval, and improved sexuality and general well-being.

Does a newly approved contraceptive pill with the active ingredient combination nomegestrol acetate and 17ß-estradiol have fewer undesirable side effects than other birth control pills? Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] available evidence supports the efficacy of pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) in decreasing the incidence of human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection among high-risk individuals, especially when used in combination with other behavioural preventive methods.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] prep was associated with decreased risk of hiv infection vs placebo or no prep after 4 months to 4 years (11 trials; relative risk [rr], 0.46 [95% ci, 0.33-0.66]; i2 = 67%; absolute risk reduction [ard], -2.0% [95% ci, -2.8% to -1.2%]).

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] hiv preexposure prophylaxis (prep) decreases risk of hiv acquisition; however, its efficacy is closely dependent on adherence.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] randomized controlled trials have demonstrated that daily oral prep dramatically reduces the risk of hiv infection when it is taken as directed.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] hiv pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) has been found to be efficacious in preventing hiv acquisition among seronegative individuals in a variety of risk groups, including men who have sex with men and people who inject drugs.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] prep as an intervention to reduce hiv transmission appears to have a safe benefit-risk profile in clinical trials.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) is highly effective in reducing the risk for hiv infection among men who have sex with men (msm) and may have an important impact in slowing down the hiv epidemic.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] although preliminary studies showed that preexposure prophylaxis (prep) lowers the hiv transmission in individuals with hiv, confirmative trials are ongoing and prep is not routinely recommended.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) is an effective and evidence-based hiv-prevention option and is recommended for individuals with substantial risk for hiv infection [1].

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] antiretroviral therapy (art) used as preexposure prophylaxis (prep) by human immunodeficiency virus (hiv)-seronegative individuals reduces the risk of acquiring hiv.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) is a highly effective, pharmacologic method of hiv prevention.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] antiretroviral (arv)-based pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) is a promising new hiv prevention strategy.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] hiv preexposure prophylaxis (prep) is an effective tool in preventing hiv infection among high-risk men who have sex with men (msm).

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] our results show that prep had minimal influence in reducing the risk of hiv transmission during natural conception in hiv-1-serodiscordant couples with a stably suppressed viral load.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep), in which hiv uninfected persons with ongoing hiv risk use antiretroviral medications as chemoprophylaxis against sexual hiv acquisition, is a promising new hiv prevention strategy.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] proof-of-concept that prep, as oral or vaginal topical tenofovir-based products, protects against sexual hiv acquisition has been demonstrated in clinical trials conducted among men who have sex with men and heterosexual men and women.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] preexposure prophylaxis (prep) involves use of antiretroviral therapy (art) daily or before and after sex to decrease risk of acquiring hiv infection.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] many individuals who stop prep remain at risk of hiv, and participants reported that proactive outreach could potentially have prevented hiv infections.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep), taken as a single daily coformulated pill containing tenofovir -emtricitabine, is a promising intervention to reduce the likelihood of hiv acquisition in at-risk individuals, including men who have sex with men.

Does PrEP reduce the risk of HIV infection? [SEP] pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) with tdf/ftc significantly reduces the risk for hiv-1 transmission, but, to date, nobody knows if prep can still be useful in case of viruses harboring resistances to tdf/ftc or if alternative antiretroviral drugs might be rather proposed in selected cases. |||

Does exercise, a restricted diet, or both together help prevent excessive weight gain during pregnancy? [SEP] evidence from this review suggests that both diet and exercise together and diet alone help women to lose weight after childbirth.

Does exercise, a restricted diet, or both together help prevent excessive weight gain during pregnancy? [SEP] preliminary evidence from this review suggests that dieting and exercise together appear to be more effective than diet alone at helping women to lose weight after childbirth, because the former improves maternal cardiorespiratory fitness level and preserves fat-free mass, while diet alone reduces fat-free mass.

Does colonoscopy reduce mortality from colorectal cancer? [SEP] through its impact on the adenoma-carcinoma sequence, colonoscopy has a central role in the detection and prevention of colorectal cancer (crc).

Does colonoscopy reduce mortality from colorectal cancer? [SEP] compared with no endoscopic screening, receipt of a screening colonoscopy was associated with a 67% reduction in the risk of death from any colorectal cancer (adjusted or (aor)=0.33, 95% ci 0.21 to 0.52).

Does colonoscopy reduce mortality from colorectal cancer? [SEP] pooled analysis showed that colonoscopy was associated with a 61% rr reduction in crc incidence (rr: 0.39; 95% ci: 0.26-0.60; i(2)=93.6%) and a 61% reduction in crc mortality (rr: 0.39; 95% ci: 0.35-0.43; i(2)=12.0%) in patients with non-malignant findings, although there was high heterogeneity for the outcome of crc incidence.

Does colonoscopy reduce mortality from colorectal cancer? [SEP] our results showed that colonoscopy was associated with a 52% rr reduction in incidence of crc (rr: 0.48, 95% ci: 0.46-0.49) and 62% rr reduction in mortality of crc (rr: 0.38, 95% ci: 0.36-0.40).

Can honey accelerate the healing of second degree burns with pain, redness and blisters?
